column4: HI, if I have 2 OS in the same disk, each of them having it separated /boot partition.
When I'm in the second installed OS I can edit the grub.cgf to selected OS1 as default, but how can I do this when I'm at OS1?
`sudo apt-get install grub-customizer`
graphical, or it was a command line interface
its graphical
thanks, and gl with your problem
if you
if you're trying to get Grub to recognize the new OS entry you may need go `sudo update grub`
what OS's are you trying to dual boot?
if I can ask, what OS's are you trying to dual boot? because if one of them is Windows, GRUB doesnt work well with windows
for now a 12.04 and a 11.10, but I intend to do it generic. An yes i run update-grub, "update-grub2" to be precise
only linuxs

https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Boot-Repair
that should set your grub menu straight and find all your OS's
APoulos, also - if you're using 11.10 - you can run Startup-Manager - sadly Startup-manager doesnt work well with 12.04
